reviewText: One of the first PC games I played back in 1994 when my parents bought me my first computer (486 DX4-100 with a Sound Blaster-compatable" soundcard and a 2x-speed CD-ROM drive
date: baby!) Under a Killing Moon made quite a racket at the time
recommended: being one of the first games that used FMV
hoursPlayed: and not just for cut-scenes but also in-game
voteText: and for being so unprecedently huge (it shipped on 4 CDs). This was cutting edge stuff back then
helpfulPercent: when some games were still shipped on several floppy disks... And than this mammoth came!\n\nAnyway
votesHelpful: technologies aside the game turned out to be really interesting and clever. I spent lots of days and nights playing it (I was 14 and had zero experience in computer adventure games at the time) but in the end I made it
votesTotal: although I used hints several times. I've been hooked on point-n-click adventure games ever since.\n\nFrankly
votesFunny: I bought this game several days ago more out of nostalgia than anything else. I thought I would play an hour or so
column17: and be on my way. Well
column19: I spent the night playing it and I'm now roughly half-way through
column20: fully intended on finishing it.\n\nMy next step would probably be Tex Murphy: The Pandora Directive
column21: which I haven't played at the time of its release due to some compatibility issues. Better late than never."

reviewText:
I never played these games when I was younger so there isn't any nostalgia with these games, however I do have a love of old FMV games.
The short and sweet reviewer:
Pros: Great story, funny most of the time, puzzles are not to difficult with a bit of thought but there is a hint system that works well in game, graphics are okay for the age of game, fun adventure game
Cons: Horrible controls, like really bad....but with a bit of playing they become managable, and for me the story and game are worth the struggle to move around a bit at first.
voteText: 22 of 23 people (96%) found this review helpful

reviewText: IntroductionTex Murphy: Under a Killing Moon is a kind of point-and-click adventure in 3D environments that uses a lot of full-motion video cuts and animations. Despite belonging to a classic" saga
date: I had never heard of this game when I got it from a bundle
recommended: so I started playing it out of curiosity holding zero nostalgia.\n\nEvaluationThe game has a noir-ish
hoursPlayed: futuristic ambient. How they don't really achieve it is part of the charm of the game. For example
voteText: you have flying cars
helpfulPercent: but you still have bricklike laptops and something like MS-DOS.\n\nThe game lacks "darkness" too: people die
votesTotal: more people are going to die
votesFunny: but still the atmosphere is so naive and Disney-esque that there is no drama
commentsCount:
no tension.

But it is still funny and humorous. I had some really good laughs with the FMV and dialogs. And that's probably the best value of the game.

I get that in its time
column16: the game had to be a start-of-the-art in both technical and production values. I remember 1994 as the year my family purchase a 486 with no multimedia equipment. But nowadays those values are very dated
column17: with graphics showing weird aberration effects
column19: lots of glitches and ugly low-res video (not only low-res
column21: but that's what you get when you play a game more than 20 years old. The FMV and the completely voiced dialogs and inner thoughts of the main character could be enough to forgive most of the sins of the game. Even nowadays
column22: a full voiced game like this one is a plus. But I have to reiterate in the sins part.\n\nControls are terrible. It shows that in that time there weren't too many references of what is proper usability. Player navigates using the mouse as if one were using an analog pad in a touchscreen (the mouse is your finger)
column23: which is very hard to control. You cannot navigate using the keyboard
column25: but still requires the keyboard to raise/lower your "head" or look up/down.\n\nThe acting and even the direction is questionable at least
column26: but it is still charming enough.\n\nPuzzles are a bit too few and easy. That is good for a "quickie"
column27: but it doesn't help the game in feeling "complete" or even rewarding. Well
column28: they are harder than those in your typical Hidden Object Game
column29: but I feel them to be below those in other point-and-click games.\n\nMost of the game is spent navigating the environments looking for objects which are
column31: easy enough to locate. An experienced
column32: inquisitive player may find every object in each room and not need to review already visited rooms
column33: although sometimes that is needed for new objects to appear.\n\nThere is yet another big flaw in the story
column34: or at least an important part of the story that is completely overlooked.\n<spoilers>\nWhen you destroy the evil guy's space station
column35: you kill HUNDREDS OF THOUSANDS of people
column36: all the population that knows of and believes in that cult
column37: you wipe them out. You are a genocide. It's a Master Plan worthy of Evil Hitler: convince the ones you want to kill that they have a Master Plan
column38: let them get all in the same place to celebrate and annihilate them in a press-any-key-to-continue-simple action. Ok
column39: these ones were not nice people
column41: they were going to kill everyone else. But next day
column42: you are giving tango lessons. WTF!\nYes
column43: ranting about it was the main driver to write this review.\nAnd let me reuse this spoiler block to say that the final puzzle (or more precisely
column44:
the lack of a "puzzle") is really anti-climatic.
</spoiler>

Finally
column45: the game has a very opportune in-game help system
column47: which makes virtually impossible to get the player stuck in the game. The game also has an introduction to the series
column48:
a score system to help you fully explore the game and a hinting system to help you not get stalled in the game.

Summary and veredictPros:
Fun

humorous game.
Short.
Voiced dialogs and FMV.
Meta-game parts: help
column53: too little Noire.\nA bit too easy and simple

column55:
I didn't find them. Save often.
Controls.
Definitely inferior to its sucessor.
I recommend the game because I enjoyed playing it. It is fun and short enough to be not repetitive or annoying."

reviewText:
This game is very good i can truly highly recommend it. You are a private detective down on his luck, looking for a break.
But boy oh boy i dont think u would expect this much trouble & drama! I won't reveal any more of the story so i dont spoil the game, but i will say this game is just awesome, with very good classic graphics, great story and amazing 3d inter active interface system.

The only small bad thing i can say about this game is it runs on Dosbox, it doesnt run on Windows 7 or Windows 8 natively.

reviewText: Under A Killing Moon" is the third game in the Tex Murphy series and is a 3D First Person Point & Click Adventure with bits of Full Motion Video. The majority of the game takes place in the slums of a post-apocalyptic San Fransisco still in the midst of World War Three. After solving a petty burglary
date: Tex is tasked with recovering a countess' precious family heirloom
recommended: a bird statuette and must rely on his expert deductive skills (or lack there-of) to tackle this case head on.\n\nThe game is full of camp (the good kind)
hoursPlayed: but also portions of comedy and really good acting
voteText: which typically unheard of in a game of this manner. So it would be fair to call it one parts "Sam & Max Hit The Road" and one parts "Myst". The game's only downside is the 3D portions. Navigating around is akin to sliding on ice and most definitely takes some getting used to. But what makes it truly a cut above the rest is it's very intuitive "hint" system that throws you a mulligan if you get lost (you earn points from conversations
votesHelpful: and solving puzzles and use them as you please).\n\nOverall
votesTotal: it's a great game that's an absolute must for fans of old school computer games and point & click adventures alike"

reviewText: This game is an old DOS game, so be prepared for terrible low-res graphics and sounds. However, unlike the first two Tex Murphy games, this one is actually playable and kind of fun. You are a detective, putting together clues to solve cases. Sometimes it gets a bit confusing (whether from the terrible graphics/gameplay, lack of explanation, or just from normal human error), but there is a HINT button that is there to help you. You can only buy" hints with points that you acquire from playing through the game on your own. Overall
recommended: old school game. It is full of full motion video (FMV) and the acting is awful! Even so
hoursPlayed: the game itself is decent and kind of fun. Since this game is super old
voteText: it's not really worth paying for by itself. If you get it in a bundle or something
helpfulPercent: give it a shot. It's decent."

reviewText: i don't have an issue with pixel hunting for clickables, the problem is confounded with the terrible 1st person perspective view and movement.   i understand the game came out in the mid 90's, but i don't think using this FPP and movement scheme should have been implemented.  im sure it looked awesome back then, but its not practical using this view when looking for stuff to click on.\n\ni really wanted to continue with the story, the voice actors are top notch, and the plot was ok, but i just couldn't deal with the FPP movement any longer when i had to look at a walkthrough because i missed a clickable that was behind a statue; so hard to find with the movement.  oh well.

reviewText:
THIS is the Tex Murphy series I've heard so much hype about?  They got James Earl Jones to work on THIS?

I played the first few minutes of the game and quit because I just couldn't stand it.  If it had just been the horrible controls and amateurish video editing then I'd have put my head down and pressed on, but that's the least of the problems with this game."

To put it bluntly
date: this game is basically what you'd get if you hired Friedberg and Seltzer to make a parody of the detective noir genre and cast a second-rate Jim Varney impersonator in the lead.  The acting
voteText: and direction aren't just bad enough to break immersion; they're so bad that you're never immersed in the first place."

reviewText: I never got around to play it before, but I was a fan of Pandora directive. Now I finally got it as a part of the Tex Murphy Classic collection.\nExcluding the firt two titles, Tex Murphy is a series of detective FMV adventure games (interactive movie") set in a post-apocalyptic future. This adventure game sub-genre was relatively popular in the 90's as digital video technologies were emerging
date: but never really lived past that time. Under a Killing Moon
recommended: is one of the early examples of that genre.\n\nWhile it was a technological marvel back in the 1993
hoursPlayed: the game didn't really age well. Stuttery FMV sequences
voteText: bad compositing effects and very early 3D environments are sometimes laughable and anything but impressive today. However I consider it part of the charm
helpfulPercent: as Tex Murphy adventures always were a mix of things that seem like they would never work well together. This retro feel actually helps to convey the atmosphere of a dystopian future
votesHelpful: although it probably wasn't intentional at the time of making.\n\nIt certainly isn't a game for everyone
votesTotal: and I'm not sure if this is the best game for the newcomers to the series (maybe start with some of the newer titles)
votesFunny: but if you like FMV adventures
column17: you should definitely give it a try. There is a cool story
column19: and couple of good laughs in this Tex Murphy adventure
column20: and you should play it for that."

reviewText: I haven't played much of it yet, I was really hooked by the Tesla Effect and wanted to check out how playable the older ones are. Actually it would be nearly the same if it wasn't for this walking with mouse ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Looking up and down with the arrow keys is also hyper sensetive. It is just awkward to control but thankfully the game is chock-full of cutscences and of course it is a classic Tex Murphy. If it wasn't for this guy or better this Actor the whole game would flop like an Grandpa Version of Justin Bieber as the opening act on a Bangels concert.\n\nIf you are new to this genre I recomend to rather go with Tesla Effect for the first time because of the much more enjoyable controls but if you like the Tesla Effect you can come around and play a bit of this old classic here, you won't regred it.

reviewText: I first played this game back in 1994 when a friend lent it to me. At a time when an Intel 66MHz DX/2, 8MB of RAM and a 2x CD-ROM were considered a beefy rig"
date: this game was also bleeding edge.\n\nThe FMV cutscenes were amazing
recommended: but it was the explorable 3D world which truly blew me away. No GPU acceleration here either
hoursPlayed: because there was no such thing in the consumer world: It's all software-rendered
voteText: texture-mapped polygons
helpfulPercent: and beautifully so. A true feat of programming for the time.\n\nBut more than that are the detailed plot & storyline
votesHelpful: and immensely well-thought-out interactivity. You can click on nearly anything visible and Tex will make some amusingly snide remark about it.\n\nThe objectives often require some creativity to figure out
votesTotal: but aren't overly difficult and can be accomplished in any particular order
votesFunny: and I appreciated that the game's creators didn't pull any cruel replay-because-you-forgot-something nonsense. (e.g. "You're on Chapter 4 but didn't get Item X in Chapter 2? Darn
commentsCount: you'll have to replay all that!") Sure
column16: there are trivial extras you can miss
column17: but nothing critical.\n\nI was surprised to enjoy playing this game 21 years later - Hard to believe it's old enough to drink! It shows it's age
column18: but with the right DOSbox scaling filter (I used advmame3x over the default of normal2x) many of the graphics are revived and look as though they might've been made yesterday.\n\nThe only thing which threw me off is the lack of any input configuration
column19: which means you cannot map keys
column20: and hence cannot use the (now-standard) WASD keys to get around. I eventually got settled with using the mouse (think default Wolfenstien 3D controls) to make my way
column21: but it still felt clunky no matter what. Whether this game supports joystick input or not I'm unsure
column23: I'd STRONGLY advise looking for a joystick-to-WASD wrapper utility. I probably would have if the game took more than 11 hours to complete.\n\nIf you're playing this game for nostalgia
column25: I'd highly recommend Under A Killing Moon."
